name: Last Mile Connectivity Project — Phase IV
fundingSource: World Bank IDA Credit USD 150m + Government Counterpart Funding
description: Phase IV of the government-funded Last Mile Connectivity Project targeting 200,000 new household connections in rural and peri-urban areas across 35 counties. Includes 11kV network extension, service line construction, and meter installation.

name: Last Mile Connectivity Project — Phase III
fundingSource: World Bank IDA Credit and AfDB Loan
description: Phase III achieved 233,500 new connections against target of 230,000. Rural counties of Marsabit, Turkana, Garissa, Wajir, and Mandera benefited most. Completed 3 months ahead of schedule.

name: Olkaria V Geothermal Power Plant — Grid Connection Works
fundingSource: KFW Development Bank and KPLC Internal Funds
description: Construction of 220kV transmission lines and substations connecting Olkaria V 165MW geothermal plant to Nairobi ring system. Project enabled displacement of expensive thermal generation, saving KES 4.5bn annually in power purchase costs.

name: Nairobi Metro Distribution Automation and Smart Grid
fundingSource: KPLC Internal Funds and European Investment Bank Loan EUR 120m
description: Comprehensive smart grid programme for Nairobi Metropolitan Area covering 1,200 km of 11kV feeders. Includes SCADA integration, automated fault management, and 800,000 smart meters. Target: reduce Nairobi SAIDI from 28 to 12 hours by 2026.

name: 400kV Suswa–Kisumu Transmission Line Phase II
fundingSource: European Investment Bank Loan EUR 200m and KPLC Bonds
description: Construction of 220km 400kV double-circuit transmission line from Suswa to Kisumu, enabling grid integration of Lake Victoria Basin industrial zone and reducing Western Kenya supply constraints. Land acquisition phase ongoing.

name: KPLC Pre-paid Smart Meter Rollout — Phase III
fundingSource: KPLC Internal Funds
description: Replacement of 500,000 post-paid meters with smart pre-paid meters. Targeting defaulting customers and new connections. Expected to reduce commercial losses by 3% (KES 1.7bn) and improve collection efficiency to 97%.

name: Kenya Airways Fleet Renewal — Boeing 787-9 Dreamliner (Phase 1)
fundingSource: Air Lease Corporation Operating Leases (USD 1.2m/aircraft/month)
description: Phased introduction of 4 Boeing 787-9 Dreamliner aircraft on lease from Air Lease Corporation. Aircraft to replace 2 ageing B777-300ER on Nairobi–London, Nairobi–New York and Nairobi–Guangzhou routes. Expected 22% reduction in fuel consumption per seat versus replaced aircraft.

name: Kenya Airways Nairobi Hub Cargo Centre Expansion
fundingSource: KQ Internal Funds and IFC Loan USD 15m
description: Expansion of JKIA cargo facility from 30,000 to 80,000 m² to position Nairobi as East Africa's primary cargo hub. Includes cold chain facility (5,000 m² pharmaceutical and perishables), automated sorting, and bonded warehouse. Target: cargo revenue KES 12bn by 2028.

name: Kenya Airways Digital Transformation — Amadeus Altéa Upgrade
fundingSource: KQ Internal Funds
description: Upgrade of Amadeus Altéa passenger services system including new crew management, revenue management, and customer experience modules. Expected to improve ancillary revenue by KES 1.2bn through dynamic pricing and unbundled fares.

name: Kenya Airways JamboJet Fleet Expansion
fundingSource: JamboJet/KQ Internal Funds and Aircraft Lease
description: Addition of 3 Bombardier Q400 turboprop aircraft to JamboJet fleet for expansion of domestic and East African regional routes to underserved destinations including Nanyuki, Isiolo, and Entebbe.

name: KPA Berths 21–24 Construction and Commissioning
fundingSource: AfDB Sovereign Loan USD 200m, China Exim Bank USD 150m, KPA Internal Funds
description: Construction of 4 new deep-water berths (each 350m long × 15m depth) at Kilindini Harbour, equipped with 4 ship-to-shore gantry cranes and 12 rubber-tyred gantry cranes. Adds 500,000 TEU annual capacity. Commissioned December 2023.

name: KPA Berths 25–26 Construction
fundingSource: KPA Retained Earnings (40%) + Long-term Debt Facility (60%)
description: Construction of 2 additional deep-water berths (Berths 25 and 26) at Kilindini Harbour, each capable of handling 22,000 TEU vessels. Will add further 300,000 TEU capacity. NEMA EIA approved October 2024. Groundbreaking ceremony scheduled September 2024.

name: KPA Kilindini Channel Deepening — Phase III
fundingSource: KPA Internal Funds and Development Bank of Southern Africa Loan
description: Deepening of Kilindini Channel from current 14m to 15.5m to accommodate fully laden 20,000 TEU vessels without tide restrictions. Emergency dredging of 3 shoaled sections to proceed first (by December 2024).

name: KPA Port Community System Phase 2 (Navis N4)
fundingSource: KPA Internal Funds
description: Upgrade to Navis N4 Terminal Operating System covering all container berths, integrated single window system for customs and shipping line documentation, and electronic gate automation. Expected to reduce port dwell time from 3.8 to 2.5 days.

name: KPA Lamu Port LAPSSET Berths 4–6 Development
fundingSource: Government of Kenya, LAPSSET Corridor Development Authority, Private Sector PPP
description: Development of Berths 4-6 at Lamu Port as part of the LAPSSET Corridor programme, to serve as the northern gateway for cargo destined for South Sudan, Ethiopia, and Central African Republic via the Lamu–Garissa–Moyale road corridor.

name: KPLC Nuclear Grid Readiness Assessment
fundingSource: KPLC Internal Funds (IAEA Technical Cooperation)
description: Independent technical assessment of Kenya National Grid readiness to integrate up to 1,000MW nuclear power from the planned Nuclear Power Plant (NPP). Assessment covers grid stability, frequency response, protection systems, and investment requirements estimated at KES 85bn for grid upgrades.

name: Kenya Airways MRO Centre of Excellence Expansion
fundingSource: KQ Internal Funds and JKIA Facility Agreement
description: Expansion of Kenya Airways MRO facility at JKIA to become the premier MRO centre in East Africa. New hangar accommodating 3 wide-body and 5 narrow-body aircraft simultaneously. Targets third-party MRO revenue of KES 3.5bn by 2026.

name: KPA Container Freight Station — Nairobi ICD Phase II
fundingSource: KPA Internal Funds and KfW Loan EUR 50m
description: Expansion of Nairobi Inland Container Depot (KICD) from 4,500 to 8,500 TEU capacity. Doubled Nairobi ICD capacity, reduced Standard Gauge Railway (SGR) port-Nairobi transit time to 8 hours, and reduced import/export dwell time by 30%.

name: KPA Mombasa Port Renewable Energy Programme
fundingSource: KPA Internal Funds and GCF (Green Climate Fund) Grant
description: Installation of 15MW rooftop solar PV system across port warehouses and administration buildings, combined with shore power supply for vessels at berth (cold ironing). Target: 25% renewable energy supply and 35% reduction in port carbon footprint.

name: KPLC Green Energy Transition Plan — Geothermal Expansion Support
fundingSource: KfW Development Bank and Green Bond Issue
description: KPLC transmission and distribution infrastructure upgrades to enable integration of 500MW additional geothermal capacity from KenGen's Olkaria VI and Suswa geothermal projects. Includes 220kV transmission lines, grid stability investments, and demand response systems.

name: Kenya Airways Sustainability — Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) Trials
fundingSource: KQ Internal Funds and ICAO CORSIA Support Programme
description: Pilot programme for Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) blending on JKIA-operated routes. Targeting 2% SAF blend on Nairobi-London route by 2025. Partnership with Neste Oil for SAF supply. Part of CORSIA compliance strategy.

name: KPLC Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) Upgrade
fundingSource: KPLC Internal Funds
description: Full SAP S/4HANA implementation replacing legacy FINESSE ERP. Scope covers finance, procurement, HR, asset management, and customer billing. Programme includes customer portal development targeting 3 million digital self-service customers by 2026.

name: KPA Workers Training and Skills Centre
fundingSource: KPA Internal Funds and International Labour Organization Grant
description: Construction of KPA Maritime Skills and Training Centre at Port Reitz, offering STCW courses, crane operator certification, stevedoring, and maritime English. Currently training 1,200 port workers annually and generating KES 85m in external training revenue.

name: Kenya Airways Codeshare Network Expansion — Gulf and Asian Partners
fundingSource: KQ Internal Funds
description: Commercial initiative to add 8 new codeshare partners including Singapore Airlines, Korean Air, and Qatar Airways (pending regulatory approvals). Expected to add 320,000 passengers and KES 2.8bn revenue annually by expanding KQ's virtual network to 280 destinations.

name: KPLC Electricity Distribution Metering Infrastructure — AMI Phase II
fundingSource: World Bank Project Support and KPLC Funds
description: Deployment of 300,000 Advanced Metering Infrastructure (AMI) smart meters across Nairobi, Mombasa, and Kisumu. Real-time consumption data enabled 18% reduction in commercial losses and KES 2.1bn revenue recovery from previously undetected meter tampering.
